metadata.case_name: Kalwa Devadattam & Ors. v. Union of India & Ors. / Kumaji Sare Mal

facts.text: Nagappa son of Pullanna resident Nandyal carried on business in yarn, drugs and forward contracts. He acquired in that business a considerable estate which was treated by him as property of the joint family of himself and his sons.

Nagappa and his sons were assessed by the Income-tax authorities to pay income-tax and super-tax in the status of a Hindu undivided family as set out in the following table -- Year of account ending 24-3-44 (1944-45): Rs. 51,116-7-0; 14-3-45 (1945-46): Rs. 21,452-1-0; 2-4-46 (1946-47): Rs. 21,012-13-0. Besides this amount of income-tax and super-tax he was assessed to pay penalty and excess profits tax aggregating to Rs. 26,602/-. The total amount of tax due for the three years of assessment 1944-45, 1945-46 and 1946-47 aggregated to Rs. 1,23,233/5/-.

Nagappa did not pay the tax. The revenue authorities of the Province of Madras, at the instance of the Income-tax Department attached 51 items of immovable property as belonging to the joint family of Nagappa and his sons and put up the same for sale under the Madras Revenue Recovery Act II of 1864. Out of these 38 items were sold and were purchased by certain persons.

Kalwa Devadattam, Kalwa Devarayulu and Kalwa Nandi Sankarappa sons of Nagappa (plaintiffs) through their mother acting as their next friend commenced suit No. 52 of 1950 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Kurnool, against the Union of India, the revenue authorities of the State of Madras, the purchasers of the properties at the auction, and Nagappa, claiming declaration that assessment orders for 1944-45, 1945-46, 1946-47 were unenforceable against 51 items, sale void and illegal, and injunction.

Plaintiffs' case: items 46 to 51 did not at any time belong to the joint family, having been acquired by them with funds provided by their maternal grandmother Seshamma, and the remaining items were not liable as allotted to them on a partition of the joint family estate before the order of assessment.

Kumaji Sare Mal filed suit No. 7 of 1944 against Nagappa for Rs. 10,022-10-6 due on yarn transactions. Dismissed by trial court as wagering contracts, but High Court decreed on 1947-03-05 holding speculative but not wagering, for Rs. 10,000/- with interest.

Deed of partition dated 1947-03-14 between Nagappa and plaintiffs, joint family estate valued approx. Rs. 1,25,000/- divided into four shares. Nagappa allotted Rs. 31,150/- property, liable for debts Rs. 12,236/4/9.

In execution of Kumaji decree, properties allotted to plaintiffs attached. Plaintiffs' objections under O.21 r.58 CPC dismissed 1948-07-12. Plaintiffs filed suit No. 54 of 1949 claiming debt avyavaharika, incompetent to sell post-partition shares.

Trial Judge (Subordinate Judge, Kurnool): properties 1-45 joint in relevant years; no s.25A(1) order, ITO bound to assess HUF; s.67 bars suit; partition real and operative on 1947-03-14 to defeat creditors incl. IT; items 46-51 not proved joint. Decreed suit 54/1949 following Schwebo case, remedy by suit for pious obligation.

High Court (Andhra Pradesh): suit against Union not maintainable, no s.25A(1) order; partition sham and nominal; items 46-51 purchased with joint funds not Seshamma; Kumaji entitled in execution as no real partition. Dismissed both suits.
Items 46-51 purchased in names of two plaintiffs by sale deed Ext. A-230 dated 1944-03-15, consideration Rs. 23,500/- (Rs.5,019/- advance, Rs.18,481/- before Sub-Registrar paid by Nagappa).
Nagappa's statement to ITO on 1948-01-19: living singly, sons divided 10 months back, registered document, guardian wife.
Nagappa maintained accounts per Telugu year, last for 1946-47 ended 1946-04-02.
Kumaji had attachment before judgment over joint family property outstanding at date of Ext. A-230, vacated 1944-08-31.
Post-partition, Nagappa settled major fraction of his share on wife Narayanamma, sold one house; continued management; family lived together.

legal_issues.text: Whether suit to set aside income-tax assessments and sales is maintainable in civil court in view of s.67 Income-tax Act.
Whether in absence of s.25A(1) order recording partition, HUF deemed to continue for assessment and recovery despite partition after liability arose.
Whether items 46-51 were separate property of plaintiffs acquired with funds from Seshamma or joint family property.
Whether partition deed dated 1947-03-14 was real and operative or sham and nominal.
Whether post-partition, creditor with decree against father can execute against son's share or must file separate suit for pious obligation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Assessment orders unenforceable against scheduled properties as partition on 1947-03-14 before assessments; items 1-45 allotted to plaintiffs; items 46-51 acquired with Seshamma's funds, not joint.
In suit 54/1949, debt avyavaharika; post-partition shares not attachable in execution of decree against father alone.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Pious obligation requires separate suit post-partition

respondent_arguments.text: Plaintiffs not entitled to question assessment correctness in civil court (s.67); precluded by s.25A(3); partition sham; items 46-51 joint family property.
Purchasers: no invalidity in assessment/sale; binding as full price paid.
Kumaji: partition sham; entitled to execute against sons' shares.

court_reasoning.text: Suit against Union fails: barred by s.67; liability arose before partition (not later than close of account year); no s.25A(1) order, deemed HUF under s.25A(3); even with order, joint/several liability under s.25A(2) proviso.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Liability to tax arises by virtue of charging section not later than close of previous year.

court_reasoning.text: Nagappa's 1948 statement claimed partition but no inquiry/order under s.25A(1); remedy by appeal s.30, not suit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Error in assessment rectified under Act, not civil suit.

court_reasoning.text: Items 46-51: plaintiffs failed to prove Seshamma funds (discrepant evidence); legitimate inference joint family funds as Nagappa paid, business profits, attachment context.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Where evidence led, judge on evidence not onus alone.

court_reasoning.text: Partition sham: timed post-decree; unequal real value; Nagappa continued management, settled/sold his share; family together; no serious differences.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere execution/registration not decisive if not intended operative.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide post-partition execution vs. suit as partition sham.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pious obligation continues post-partition but father's disposing power ends.

holdings.text: Suit to challenge assessment/sale not maintainable by s.67 Income-tax Act.
Absence of s.25A(1) order deems HUF continued; tax recoverable from family property notwithstanding partition.
Items 46-51 joint family property liable for tax.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wallace Brothers and Co, Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City and Bombay Suburban District
precedents_cited.relevance: Liability to tax arises not later than close of previous year.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sardar Bahadur Sir Sunder Singh Majithia v. Commissioner of Income-tax, United and Central Provinces
precedents_cited.relevance: Scheme of s.25A: assessment on disrupted family, joint/several liability.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Punjab, North-West Frontier and Delhi Provinces v. Lahore Tribune Trust, Lahore
precedents_cited.relevance: Remedies only under Act, s.67 bars civil suit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Schwebo K.S.R.M. Firm through Partner Govindan, alias Ramanathan Chettiar v. Subbiah alias Shanmugham Chettiar
precedents_cited.relevance: Post-partition, son's share not executable for father's debt; separate suit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Katragadda China Ramayya v. Chiruvella Venkunraju
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench: post-partition, separate suit for pious obligation.
Bombay view: execute by impleading son.
Pious obligation continues post-partition; father's alienation power ends.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Bars civil suit; deems HUF continued without partition order; joint/several liability post-partition.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Revenue Recovery Act II of 1864
statutes_cited.relevance: Attachment and sale of properties for tax recovery.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Objections to attachment; executing court powers.

outcome.summary: Both Civil Appeals Nos. 641 and 642 of 1961 dismissed. Suit No.52/1950 against Union fails as barred by s.67, no s.25A order, liability pre-partition; items 46-51 joint. Suit No.54/1949 fails as partition sham; Kumaji entitled to execute.

key_quotes.text: "Liability to tax arises by virtue of the charging section alone, and it arises not later than the close of the previous year though quantification of the amount payable is postponed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines when tax liability arises, before partition.

key_quotes.text: "Section 25A merely sets up machinery for avoiding difficulties... while at the same time affirming the liability of such members... jointly and severally to satisfy the total tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains s.25A effect on post-disruption recovery.

key_quotes.text: "The mere execution of the deed is not decisive of the question whether it was intended to be effective."
key_quotes.speaker: court
